commands.name: system
commands.longdesc: The given ID can either be a 5-character ID, a Discord account @mention, or a Discord account ID. Leave blank to show your own system.

subcommands.name: new
subcommands.description: Creates a new system registered to your account.

subcommands.name: name
subcommands.description: Changes the name of your system.

subcommands.name: description
subcommands.description: Changes the description of your system.

subcommands.name: avatar
subcommands.description: Changes the avatar of your system.
subcommands.longdesc: **NB:** Avatar URLs must be a *direct* link to an image (ending in .jpg, .gif or .png), AND must be under the size of 1000x1000 (in both dimensions), AND must be smaller than 1 MB. If the avatar doesn't show up properly, it is likely one or more of these rules aren't followed. If you need somewhere to host an image, you can upload it to Discord or Imgur and copy the *direct* link from there.

subcommands.name: tag
subcommands.description: Changes the system tag of your system.
subcommands.longdesc:
The system tag is a snippet of text added to the end of your member's names when proxying. Many servers require the use of a system tag for identification. Leave blank to clear.

**NB:** You may use standard Discord emojis, but server/Nitro emojis won't work.

subcommands.name: timezone
subcommands.description: Changes the time zone of your system.
subcommands.longdesc:
This affects all dates or times displayed in PluralKit. Leave blank to clear.

**NB:** You need to specify a location (eg. the nearest major city to you). This allows PluralKit to dynamically adjust for time zone or DST changes.

subcommands.name: delete
subcommands.description: Deletes your system.
subcommands.longdesc:
The command will ask for confirmation.

**This is irreversible, and will delete all information associated with your system, members, proxied messages, and accounts.**

subcommands.name: fronter
subcommands.description: Shows the current fronter of a system.

subcommands.name: fronthistory
subcommands.description: Shows the last 10 switches of a system.

subcommands.name: frontpercent
subcommands.description: Shows the aggregated front history of a system within a given time frame.
subcommands.longdesc: Percentages may add up to over 100% when multiple members cofront. Time frame will default to 1 month.

subcommands.name: list
subcommands.description: Shows a paginated list of a system's members. Add 'full' for more details.

commands.name: link
commands.description: Links this system to a different account.
commands.longdesc: This means you can manage the system from both accounts. The other account will need to verify the link by reacting to a message.

commands.name: unlink
commands.description: Unlinks this account from its system.
commands.longdesc: You can't unlink the only account in a system.

commands.name: member
commands.longdesc: The given member name can either be the name of a member in your own system or a 5-character member ID (in any system).

subcommands.name: new
subcommands.description: Creates a new system member.

subcommands.name: rename
subcommands.description: Changes the name of a member.

subcommands.name: description
subcommands.description: Changes the description of a member.
examples: member Jack description Very cool guy.

subcommands.name: avatar
subcommands.description: Changes the avatar of a member.
subcommands.longdesc: **NB:** Avatar URLs must be a *direct* link to an image (ending in .jpg, .gif or .png), AND must be under the size of 1000x1000 (in both dimensions), AND must be smaller than 1 MB. If the avatar doesn't show up properly, it is likely one or more of these rules aren't followed. If you need somewhere to host an image, you can upload it to Discord or Imgur and copy the *direct* link from there.

subcommands.name: proxy
subcommands.description: Changes the proxy tags of a member.
subcommands.longdesc: The proxy tags describe how to proxy this member through Discord. You must pass an "example proxy" of the word "text", ie. how you'd proxy the word "text". For example, if you want square brackets for this member, pass `[text]`. Emojis are allowed.

subcommands.name: pronouns
subcommands.description: Changes the pronouns of a member.
subcommands.longdesc: These will be displayed on their profile. This is a free text field, put whatever you'd like :)
examples: member Jill pronouns she/her or they/them
member Jones pronouns use whatever lol

subcommands.name: color
subcommands.description: Changes the color of a member.
subcommands.longdesc:
This will displayed on their profile. Colors must be in hex format (eg. #ff0000).

**NB:** Due to a Discord limitation, the colors don't affect proxied message names.

subcommands.name: birthday
subcommands.description: Changes the birthday of a member.
subcommands.longdesc: This must be in YYYY-MM-DD format, or just MM-DD if you don't want to specify a year.

subcommands.name: delete
subcommands.description: Deletes a member.
subcommands.longdesc:
This command will ask for confirmation.

**This is irreversible, and will delete all data associated with this member.**

commands.name: switch
commands.description: Registers a switch with the given members.
commands.longdesc: You may specify multiple members to indicate cofronting.

subcommands.name: move
subcommands.description: Moves the latest switch back or forwards in time.
subcommands.longdesc: You can't move a switch into the future, and you can't move a switch further back than the second-latest switch (which would reorder front history).

subcommands.name: delete
subcommands.description: Deletes the latest switch. Will ask for confirmation.

subcommands.name: out
subcommands.description: Will register a 'switch-out' - a switch with no associated members.

commands.name: log
commands.description: Sets a channel to log all proxied messages.
commands.longdesc: This command is restricted to the server administrators (ie. users with the Administrator role).

commands.name: message
commands.description: Looks up information about a message by its message ID.
commands.longdesc:
You can obtain a message ID by turning on Developer Mode in Discord's settings, and rightclicking/longpressing on a message.

**Tip:** Reacting to a message with ‚ùì will DM you this information too.

commands.name: invite
commands.description: Sends the bot invite link for PluralKit.

commands.name: import
commands.longdesc: You will need to type the command, *then* send a new message containing the .json file as an attachment.

commands.name: export
commands.description: Exports your system to a .json file.
commands.longdesc: This will respond with a .json file containing your system and member data, useful for importing elsewhere.

commands.name: token
commands.description: DMs you a token for using the PluralKit API.

subcommands.name: refresh
subcommands.description: Refreshes your API token.
subcommands.longdesc: This will invalide the old token and DM you a new one. Do this if your token leaks in any way.

commands.name: help
commands.description: Displays help for a given command.

subcommands.name: proxy
subcommands.description: Displays a short guide to the proxy functionality.

commands.name: commands
commands.description: Displays a paginated list of commands

root.name: PluralKit
root.content:
PluralKit is a bot designed for plural communities on Discord. It allows you to register systems, maintain system information, set up message proxying, log switches, and more.

**Who's this for? What are systems?**
Put simply, a system is a person that shares their body with at least 1 other sentient "self". This may be a result of having a dissociative disorder like DID/OSDD or a practice known as Tulpamancy, but people that aren't tulpamancers or undiagnosed and have headmates are also systems.

**Why are people's names saying [BOT] next to them? What's going on?**
These people are not actually bots, this is simply a caveat to the message proxying feature of PluralKit.
Type `pk;help proxy` for an in-depth explanation.

root.name: Getting started
root.content:
To get started using the bot, try running the following commands.
**1**. `pk;system new` - Create a system if you haven't already
**2**. `pk;member add John` - Add a new member to your system
**3**. `pk;member John proxy [text]` - Set up square brackets as proxy tags
**4**. You're done!
**5**. Optionally, you may set an avatar from the URL of an image with:
`pk;member John avatar [link to image]`

Type `pk;help member` for more information.

root.name: Useful tips
root.content:
React with ‚ùå on a proxied message to delete it (if you sent it!).
React with ‚ùì on a proxied message to look up information about it, like who sent it.

root.name: More information
root.content:
For a full list of commands, type `pk;commands`.
For a more in-depth explanation of message proxying, type `pk;help proxy`.
If you're an existing user of the Tupperbox proxy bot, type `pk;import` to import your data from there.

root.name: Support server
root.content: We also have a Discord server for support, discussion, suggestions, announcements, etc: <https://discord.gg/PczBt78>

proxy.name: Proxying
proxy.content:
Proxying through PluralKit lets system members have their own faux-account with their name and avatar.
You'll type a message from your account in *proxy tags*, and PluralKit will recognize those tags and repost the message with the proper details, with the minor caveat of having the **[BOT]** icon next to the name (this is a Discord limitation and cannot be circumvented).

To set up a member's proxy tag, use the `pk;member <name> proxy [example match]` command.

You'll need to give the bot an "example match" containing the word `text`. Imagine you're proxying the word "text", and add that to the end of the command. For example: `pk;member John proxy [text]`. That will set the member John up to use square brackets as proxy tags. Now saying something like `[hello world]` will proxy the text "hello world" with John's name and avatar. You can also use other symbols, letters, numbers, et cetera, as prefixes, suffixes, or both. `J:text`, `$text` and `text]` are also examples of valid example matches.
